content: Copyright is the exclusive right to reproduce, distribute, perform, display, and exploit an original work of authorship. The 2001 Supreme Court case New York Times Co. v. Tasini involved litigation over the exclusive rights of freelance authors. In the 2001 Supreme Court case New York Times Co. v. Tasini, freelance authors sued publishers for reproducing and distributing their work without permission. The court ruled in favor of the authors, stating that the Copyright Act does not permit publishers to reproduce freelance works. The Supreme Court ruled in the case New York Times Co. v. Tasini that publishers cannot reproduce freelance works electronically without specific authorization, requiring them to obtain a separate license from the author. This decision led to the removal of many freelance works from electronic databases and activated preexisting class action infringement suits.
